questions.text: A 66-year-old woman presents with dysphagia and intermittent vomiting. Endoscopy shows a tight lower oesophageal sphincter suggestive of achalasia. Which of the following medical therapies is most effective?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Botulinum toxin, injected into the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) under endoscopic guidance, inhibits acetylcholine release from nerve endings and improves dysphagia for at least 6 months.
  • Nifedipine, nitrate,s or sildenafil can also be used, but are less effective.
  • The other therapies for achalasia are pneumatic dilation and Laparoscopic Heller's LES myotomy.

Explanation for incorrect options:

Diltiazem (Option A) – A calcium channel blocker, but not commonly used or effective for achalasia treatment compared to other agents like nitrates or nifedipine.
Bismuth (Option B) – Used for GI ulcers and infections; has no role in managing motility disorders like achalasia.
Glyceryl trinitrate (Option C) – Can lower LES pressure temporarily but is less effective and shorter-acting than botulinum toxin.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man who usually drinks only 2 units of alcohol a day went on an alcohol binge with his friends. On that day, he vomited 10 times and was brought to the hospital feeling very unwell. He has not previously had any symptoms of dyspepsia or abdominal pains. During physical assessment, he vomits a large bowlful of blood. What is the likely cause of his haemetemesis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is a case of Mallory Weiss tear.

  • Longitudinal tear in the mucosaat the gastroesophageal junction.
  • Caused by forceful or prolonged vomitingor coughing.
  • They may also be caused by epileptic convulsions.
  • Usually seen in alcoholics, bulimia nervosa patients.
  • The tear may be followed by vomiting bright red blood or by passing blood in the stool.
  • Active bleed can be treated by endoscopy (band ligation or coaptive coagulation).

A transmural rupture at the gastroesophageal junction is called Boerhaave's syndrome.

Oesophageal varices (Option A) – Typically occur in patients with chronic liver disease and portal hypertension; this patient has no history suggestive of either.
Duodenal ulcer (Option B) – More likely to cause melena or occult bleeding; not usually associated with sudden, profuse hematemesis following vomiting.
Gastritis (Option D) – Can cause upper GI bleeding, but less likely to result in sudden massive hematemesis after repeated vomiting.

questions.text: A 28-year-old intravenous drug user complains about severe epigastric pains, nausea, and vomiting. He has upper GI endoscopy, which shows small areas of ulceration and white plaques. Which of the following is the best treatment option?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is a patient with possible HIV who has oesophageal candidiasis (white plaques on endoscopy).

  • Candida is normally found in the throat but can become pathogenic and produce esophagitis in a compromised host.
  • Candida albicans is the most common cause.
  • Oral fluconazolefor 14-21 days is the preferred treatment.
  • Patients refractory to fluconazole may respond to voriconazole or posaconazole.

Metronidazole (Option A) – Effective against anaerobes and protozoa, but not used for fungal infections like candidiasis.
Amoxicillin (Option B) – A penicillin antibiotic, useful for bacterial infections but ineffective against fungal pathogens such as Candida.
Ranitidine (Option C) – An H2 blocker used for acid suppression; does not treat infectious causes like Candida esophagitis.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presents with 2 bowls full of hematemesis. He drinks 10 pints of beer a day and has done so for 10 years. Upper GI endoscopy reveals oesophageal varices. Which of the following is effective in reducing the rates of rebleeding in the future?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Non-selective beta blockers (propranolol, nadolol) can be used for reducing rebleeding in oesophageal varices. They work by decreasing hepatic venous pressure gradient and thereby decreasing portal hypertension.

Lisinopril (Option A) – An ACE inhibitor used for hypertension and heart failure; no role in portal hypertension or variceal bleeding.
Simvastatin (Option C) – A statin used for dyslipidemia; not effective in preventing variceal rebleeding.
Ranitidine (Option D) – An H2 blocker that reduces acid secretion; does not address portal hypertension or variceal pressure.

questions.text: A 44-year-old Asian man presents with epigastric pains of a burning nature. The pain was worse at night. He was prescribed combinations of antacids for a year, and this did not relieve his symptoms entirely. He had an endoscopy which did not show any significant abnormalities 3 months ago. Which is the best test for further investigation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient presents with features of gastroesophageal reflux disease(GERD). In some cases of GERD, endoscopic signs may be absent due to
    • A partially treated disease
    • In nonerosive reflux disease, the most common cause.
  • In such instances, 24 hour oesophageal pH studycan demonstrate excessive esophageal exposure to refluxed gastric fluid, the physiologic abnormality of GERD.
  • Urease breath test is done to identify Helicobacter pylori. (Option B ruled out)
  • Gastric biopsy is done in cases of suspected gastric carcinoma. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 67 year old ex-publican presented to his GP complaining of difficulty swallowing for the past two months. The difficulty started several weeks ago with food sticking. He also complained more recently of pain from swallowing. An OGD and biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma of the oesophagus. All of the following can be risk factors except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Barrett's oesophagus is associated with adenocarcinoma of oesophagus.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman presents with a history of worsening dysphagia over many years. A barium swallow performed shows narrowing at the level of the gastroesophageal junction. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This is a case of achalasiacardia caused by loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus.
  • It is thought to be an autoimmune process linked to latent HSV infection in genetically susceptible individuals.
  • Barium swallow:A Narrowing at the level of the LES (Bird beak appearance) and various degrees of megaesophagus (esophageal dilation) as the esophagus is gradually stretched by retained food.
  • Manometrycan also be done for establishing the diagnosis. The diagnostic criteria for achalasia with esophageal manometry are impaired LES relaxation and absent peristalsis.

Oesophageal carcinoma (Option A) – Can cause dysphagia but usually progresses more rapidly and is associated with weight loss or other constitutional symptoms.

Oesophagitis (Option B) – Typically presents with odynophagia and heartburn rather than progressive mechanical dysphagia.

Barrett's oesophagus (Option C) – A complication of GERD; does not cause narrowing at the LES or long-standing progressive dysphagia.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man who is on warfarin for atrial fibrillation is complaining of worsening breathlessness over the last 2 months. On examination, he had an irregular heartbeat, blood pressure of 110 / 60 mmHg, and he looked pale.
There was no evidence of organomegaly.
Investigations show:
Haemoglobin 8.5 g/dL
MCV 70 fL
PLT 160 x 10^9/L
His upper gastrointestinal tract endoscopy and colonoscopy were normal.
What is the next best investigation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient has microcytic anaemia and is also on warfarin. So the priority is to rule out bleeding.
  • Since upper GI endoscopy and colonoscopy were normal, the next step would be capsule endoscopy, which helps to see bleeds in the small bowel. In this case, angiodysplasia of the small bowel could be a cause of bleeding.
  • In capsule endoscopy, a patient swallows a small pill which emits a radio frequency that is picked up by a sensor that the patient wears over several hours. Images are then downloaded as a continuous movie.
  • Another possible cause of GI bleed in a patient with AF is mesenteric insufficiency, which will be characterized by abdominal pain postprandial. In that case ,mesenteric angiography will be the investigation.

Barium enema (Option A) – Primarily used to visualize the large intestine, but this patient already had a normal colonoscopy; it won’t help evaluate small bowel bleeding.

Small bowel enema (Option B) – Less sensitive and rarely used today; has largely been replaced by capsule endoscopy for small bowel evaluation.

Mesenteric angiography (Option D) – Useful in acute or ongoing significant bleeding, or suspected ischemia; not first-line in stable, chronic microcytic anemia with no abdominal pain.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with a history of intermittent, but slowly progressive dysphagia for both solids and liquids. He has pain on swallowing and has regurgitation of food swallowed several hours earlier. He has not lost weight. Barium swallow demonstrates proximal dilatation of the oesophagus and failure of relaxation of the lower oesophageal sphincter. Which treatment option is best in the long term?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The diagnosis is achalasia cardia. This is a functional obstruction at the lower oesophageal sphincter caused by a failure of relaxation.
  • Heller's oesophageal myotomy (surgical division of the lower oesophageal sphincter) is the best treatment option. It can be done via an abdominal incision or laparoscopically. It is often combined with fundoplication for reflux.
  • Pneumatic dilation is another procedure done for achalasia.
  • Per Oral Esophageal Myotomy(POEM) is the latest treatment for Achalasia and is as effective as Heller's Myotomy with few complications and early recovery.
  • Botulinum toxin injection can be used to treat achalasia. But it is a temporary measure.

Sengstaken Blakemore tube (Option A) – Used for acute variceal bleeding, not for achalasia or functional esophageal obstruction.
Amyl nitrite (Option B) – A vasodilator with no therapeutic role in achalasia; not used in GI motility disorders.
Intrasphincteric botulinum toxin (Option D) – Temporarily relieves symptoms by relaxing the LES, but not effective long-term; reserved for patients unfit for surgery.

questions.text: A 52-year-old lady complains of epigastric burning pains due to stress. She finally undergoes a UGI endoscopy,which shows gastro-oesophageal reflux. Which medication is the most effective for her condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The main pharmacological therapy for GERD is inhibition of gastric acid suppression.
  • Proton pump inhibitorssuch as omeprazole, lansoprazole and pantoprazole are more effective than H2 receptor blockers such as ranitidine, cimetidine or nizatidine. Healing in oesophagitis is better with a PPI.
  • Bismuth is a mucosal protective agent used in the treatment of peptic ulcer disease.
  • Magnesium hydroxide is an antacid. It is not as effective as PPI for GERD.

Nizatidine (Option A) – An H2 receptor blocker; less effective than PPIs in reducing acid secretion and healing esophagitis in GERD.
Bismuth (Option B) – Used for peptic ulcer disease and H. pylori regimens; not the first-line treatment for GERD.
Magnesium hydroxide (Option C) – An antacid that provides short-term relief but lacks long-term efficacy seen with PPIs.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents with a six-hour history of profuse vomiting and over the last two hours, has developed left-sided chest pain and dyspnoea. On examination, he had a pulse of 110 beats per minute, regular and a blood pressure of 168/90 mmHg. On palpation, he had crepitus over the left supraclavicular region and neck, reduced heart sounds and left basilar crackles, plus some dullness to percussion over the right base of the chest. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This man has a history of vomiting, which then progressed to chest pain.
  • The most relevant finding on examination is the crepitus over the chest, indicating surgical emphysema. The most probable cause is therefore spontaneous rupture of the oesophagus, secondary to forceful vomiting, called Boerhaave's Syndrome.
  • Mackler's triad(vomiting, chest pain, and surgical emphysema) is classical but absent in almost half the cases. The chest x-ray (CXR) may reveal the surgical emphysema, and a gastrografin swallow is diagnostic.
  • A CT scan should be performed if a gastrografin swallow is not possible or negative.

Aortic dissection (Option A) – Typically presents with sudden tearing chest pain radiating to the back, often with unequal pulses; not associated with vomiting or surgical emphysema.
Aspiration pneumonia (Option B) – Can follow vomiting but usually causes fever, cough, and localized lung findings, not surgical emphysema or chest crepitus.
Perforated peptic ulcer (Option D) – Causes acute abdominal pain with signs of peritonitis, not chest crepitus or respiratory symptoms.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman presents with regurgitation of foul-smelling food, weight loss, chronic cough, and halitosis unresponsive to dental care. Her partner notes worsening symptoms over the past year. On exam, a gurgling neck mass is noted during swallowing. Vitals and labs are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The history of regurgitation of rotten food, coupled with chronic cough and a gurgling mass on examination, fits best with a pharyngeal pouch (Zenker's diverticulum). Aspiration of food from the pouch may lead to pneumonia in some cases.

  • Zenker's diverticulum is a pulsion diverticulum where pharyngeal mucosa herniates through the weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor.
  • Management involves either diverticulectomyfor larger lesions, or Dohlman's procedure for smaller pouches.
  • Whilst GERD is a possible alternative diagnosis, a pouch would not be found on examination. (Option B ruled out)
  • Achalasia is usually associated with progressive dysphagia to both liquids and solids, oesophageal carcinoma with progressive dysphagia first to solids then liquids. (Option A ruled out)
  • Plummer-Vinson's disease is associated with progressive dysphagia due to oesophageal webs. (Option D ruled out)
